oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Christopher Ammonss1970 selective service card shows his name and signature on one side and physical description on the reverse. The classification of IV-A would have exempted him from service (for those whose military obligation was completed, or for only surviving sons of a family in which the father, or one or more sons or daughters, were killed or died in the line of duty while in the Armed Forces, or subsequently died as a result of such service).

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The U.S. Selective Service System is the agency that collects and maintains data on potential military conscription registrants. Most male U.S. citizens and male immigrant non-citizens between the ages of 18 and 25 are required by law to register within 30 days of their 18th birthday. Christopher Ammons enlisted in the Army on June 1, 1967, serving with the 1st Infantry Division and later with the 194th Military Police.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two-page typed Special Order No. 188 contains military orders for a number of individuals plus a short note to his parents concerning his orders. On page two of the document are the orders assigning Christopher Ammons to his Vietnam unit. The note is dated August 16, 1967.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-: Vietnam War, 1961-1975; United States Army. Infantry Division, 1st; Fort McClellan (Ala.); Military orders
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Christopher Ammons enlisted in the U.S. Army on June 1, 1967. He did his basic training at Fort Campbell, Kentucky, and infantry training at Fort McClellan, Alabama. He was sent to Vietnam in early November 1967, and assigned to the First Infantry Division in Company A, 1st Battalion, 16th Infantry.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ammons letter from Fort Campbell before beginning basic training

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ammons's four-page letter on U.S. Army stationery to his mother and father describes his first days in the Army. He relates the military routine, getting his dog tags, standing fire watch, and waiting for his uniform. He remarks on the fact that many in his barracks had been in the National Guard, while others were drafted. Ammons enlisted on June 1, 1967, one week after he graduated from high school.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Basic Training (Military education); Fort Campbell (Ky. and Tenn.); Ammons, Christopher D., 1948- ; Vietnam War, 1961-1975; United States. Army. Infantry Division, 1st
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Christopher Ammons was born in Norfolk, Virginia in 1948. He enlisted in the Army on June 1, 1967, and served with the 1st Infantry Division and later with the 194th Military Police Company. He served two tours in Vietnam, 1967-1968 and 1969-1970. Ammons began his service as a replacement after the Tet Offensive and patrolled the Iron Triangle during his 1st tour. He briefly returned to the U.S. in 1968 and was stationed at the armory at Fort Bragg. He returned to Vietnam as an MP in 1969.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four-page letter written on Fort Campbell stationery by Christopher Ammons from basic training to his family. He details gathering together some items and visiting a museum, but the majority of the letter describes and lauds PVT Smith (Smitty). Smitty, a veteran of the Korean War, volunteered for Vietnam. In Korea he was a member of the 2nd Infantry Division and was nominated for the Congressional Medal of Honor.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Basic Training (Military education); Fort Campbell (Ky. And Tenn.); Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-; Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Korean War, 1950-1953; United States. Army. Infantry Division, 1st; United States. Army. Infantry Division, 2nd
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 2nd Infantry Division (the Indianhead Division) was activated on October 26, 1917 at Beaumont, France. The motto of the Division is "Second to None." The 2nd Division proved the first unit of reinforcements to reach Korea directly from the United States when fighting broke out in the summer of 1950. It was the first unit to break out of the Pusan Perimeter and drive with the 8th Army to the Manchurian border.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two-page letter written by Ammons to his family on the day he arrived in Vietnam. He describes conditions and housing at the 90th Replacement Battalion headquarters, 22 miles north of Saigon; the appearance and poverty of the Vietnamese villagers; and the assignment of PVT Smith (Smitty) to the 4th Infantry Division. He relates the instructions he was given if "Charlie" shells the 90th Replacement Battalion area. He would stay at this outpost briefly until assigned as a replacement.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two-page handwritten letter from Ammons to his family telling of his assignment to the 1st Infantry Division in Company A, 1st Battalion, 16th Infantry. He describes sewing on his division patch and the stripes that represent his PFC E-3 rank. He relates to his family that his processing at the 1st Infantry Replacement Detachment sixteen miles northeast of Saigon is almost complete, and he will soon be joining his unit.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 1st Infantry Division, the oldest division in the United States Army, is referred to as "The Big Red One"--an allusion to the graphic on the shoulder patch; it is also known as "The Fighting First." The 1st Infantry Division was the first divisional unit to fight in Vietnam and sustained 6,146 killed in action during the conflict.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-page handwritten letter written from Ammons to his family recounting his attendance at the Bob Hope USO show on Christmas Eve in 1967. He describes being issued clean fatigues, flying on a Chinook helicopter to Lai Khe Base Camp, and viewing Hope with his customary golf club and girls. Back with the platoon, Chistmas Eve carols are interupted, but Christmas Day involves radio calls, packages, Santa in a Huey, the 1st Infantry Band, and Christmas lunch with the General.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-page handwritten letter from Ammons at Lai Khe Base Camp to his family describing his assignment to the 3rd Platoon as a Rifleman. He will be carrying the M79 grenade launcher, two Claymore mines, trip flares, grenades, and a .45 caliber pistol. Ammons also divulges that he attended church and memorial services for two recently killed platoon members. He mentions that his anticipated date to leave Vietnam is November 5, 1968.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter to his family dated Nov. 26, 1967, begins, "At 9:30 this morning seven of us hopped aboard the truck to take us to the outer edge of the perimeter. We were going for a 3 click (3,000 meters) patrol outside the camp." On his first patrol he found propoganda leaflets in a cleared area, rice paddies, water buffaloes, children asking for cigarettes, and pot growing in a field. He ends as follows: "All the days are the same no Sat. or Sundays, it just seems like the same day over and over again."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four page letter from Christopher Ammons to his family about losing his 45 cal. pistol on a 'Road Clearance' operation. They searched for it for hours but in the end had to fill out a statement of loss. His platoon leader told him, he doesn't think I should pay for it since I was operating in a 'combat situation.' " He states that they are still at Thunder IV and they have heard that "21,000" Communists" have been killed in their offensive. He ends with, "See you in Nov. 68."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Seven-page letter written by Christopher Ammons recounting a sniper attack on his company the previous day that claimed the lives of four soldiers. While on patrol 6,000 meters southwest of Saigon, Ammons's squad comes under sniper attack, and for the first time, he sees the enemy. He is pinned in a canal by sniper fire and cut off from the rest of the company, but his lieutenant is mortally wounded. Artillery and another platoon eventually come to the aid of his squad.

oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Five-page handwritten letter from Christopher Ammons to his family describing a 7-day search and destroy mission in the woods of Song Be. Ammons's company located Viet-Cong base camps and bunkers as they "dug in" six times during the operation. Heavy artillery and air strikes were eventually called in on three Viet-Cong companies in the woods causing numerous casualties. Ammons dubbed the Song Be area "the worst."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four-page letter handwritten letter by Christopher Ammons to his family that announces his promotion to sergeant. He describes his fourth visit to Song Be for another seven-day search-and-destroy mission that ended with the discovery of numerous Viet-Cong stores. Some of the supplies were U. S. aid, and he expresses his anger that we were accidentally funding Viet-Cong operations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-page handwritten letter by Christopher Ammons to his family in which he states that he is now the oldest member of his platoon. He is destined next for a mission between Highway 13 (Thunder Road) and the Song Be River. Ammons relates the experience of the rain, listening to James Brown on Lai Khe Armed Forces Radio Service, and his disillusionment with the war.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two-page letter in which Christopher Ammons describes returning from R&R in Sydney to learn that his units designation had changed from the 194th MP Company to the 61st MP Company. He describes the new operating area and how the changes affect him. He provides some details about his time in Sydney and includes a list of clothing that he had bought there and shipped home, mentioning that he might need these for school after his return.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ammons's letter describing a South Korean plane crash on Vung Chua
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-page letter describes a plane crash on Vung Chua that killed eight South Korean officers. (The plane, still visible on the mountain, and a nearby monument are pictured in Ammons's photos.) No one knows why the plane was so far from the Qui Nhon Airfield, where it was trying to land. Ammons, describing the current inclement weather, conjectures that the thick cloud cover and heavy rain may have confused the pilot.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-page letter written from Dong Tam, final headquarters base camp of the 9th Infantry Division. Ammons describes an air assault in which the platoon was pinned down in knee-deep water under heavy fire by the Viet-Cong. He writes, "The leeches were terrible," and people's feet were damaged from being in the water for so long. The attack resulted in 13 casualties. This letter also mentions the Plain of Reeds (Dong Thap Muoi).

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The small two-engine plane crashed on the southeast side of Vung Chua Mountain on November 11, 1969. It carried eight high-ranking officers, including two colonels who were to be promoted to brigadier general on January 1, 1970. The plane was scheduled to land at the Qui Nhon Air Field, but bad weather brought it down two-and-a-half miles southwest of Qui Nhon.

United States. Army. Military Police Company, 194th; Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Vietnam; Qui Nhon (Vietnam); Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-; Submachine guns; Viet-Cong
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Christopher Ammons was born in Norfolk, Virginia, on April 18, 1948. He enlisted in the Army on June 1, 1967, serving with the 1st Infantry Division and later with the 194th Military Police Company. He served two tours in Vietnam, 1967-1968 and 1969-1970. Chris began his service as a replacement after the Tet Offensive and patrolled the Iron Triangle during his first tour. Returning to the US in 1968, he was stationed at Fort Bragg. He returned to Vietnam as an MP in 1969.

Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Vietnam; Qui Nhon (Vietnam); Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-; Military helicopters -- United States -- History; Vietnam War, 1961-1975 -- Aerial operations, American; UH-1 (Helicopter)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The UH-1 (or as it was originally designated the HU-1) "Huey" is one of the most recognizable and widely used helicopters in the world. During the Vietnam conflict, Huey's were used for many purposes including MedEvac, command and control, air assault, personnel and material transport, etc. It has several distinctive characteristics such as a rounded nose, a twin-bladed rotor, and the loud "whomp-whomp" sound the helicopter makes in flight. Approximately 7,000 UH-1 aircraft saw service in Vietnam.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: According to Ammons, regulations for carrying ammunition for the M-60 machine gun were relaxed for patrols around Vung Chua Mountain. During his first tour in the front lines of the delta, he said, ammunition was stored in boxes. These boxes were hard to carry, but kept the rounds clean and prevented jamming. On Vung Chua ammunition was carried more casually whenever the threat of enemy attack was reduced.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 1st Signal Brigade was activated on April 1, 1966, in order to place tactical and strategic communications in Southeast Asia under a single, unified command. Its mission was to install, operate, and maintain a complex communications system for forces spread out over 60,000 square miles.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Patrols were the most common assignment for the soldiers of the security detachment on Vung Chua. Patrols were sent out to check for Viet Cong activity and to set flares, mines, and seismic detectors.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military personnel; Soldiers; Uniforms; Military uniforms; Arms & armament

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Various kinds of seismic detection devices were used in Vietnam. Ammons has said that a specialist in the use of this equipment was attached to his unit, and Chris frequently aided in their installation. These devices detected footsteps of intruders, but were frequently set off by Vietnamese wildlife or the tremors caused by passing aircraft.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter by Christopher Ammons describing a road clearance operation at Thunder IV. Both squads patrolled all day, then took up a night defensive position on armored personnel carriers. He writes about trying to kill a rat ("some as big as cats") with some of his friends and mentions reading about the race riots taking place in the U.S.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Christopher Ammons telling about meeting Thomas Page, a friend from Clarksville, in Qui Nhon. He and Page, a truck driver in the army, had a long conversation. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Soldiers waiting to leave Vietnam from Cam Ranh Bay. There are dozens of men in uniforms and hats standing around a booth marked with the sign "507th Replacement Company." Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Vietnam; Cam Ranh Bay (Vietnam)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: According to Ammons, two or three formations would gather in the central location on the base at Cam Ranh Bay to hear the reading of the names of men who were leaving Vietnam to return home. The formations would wait until the list was read, after which time those whose names were called flew out of Cam Ranh Bay back to the United States.

Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Vietnam; Qui Nhon (Vietnam)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Claymore anti-personnel mines contain a C-4 explosive charge and approximately 700 steel balls about the size of #4 birdshot. They can be detonated by remote control. When detonated they distribute the munitions in a 60-degree fan-shaped pattern because of the convex shape of the front of the charge. Thus a mine acts much like a large shotgun, peppering the area with metal fragments up to 100 meters in front of the mine.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pictured are the large tropospheric arrays on top of the mountain. The tropospheric array was designed to bounce microwave radio signals into the atmosphere and then back down to receivers. This system was extremely effective in transmitting signals in mountainous or densely forested regions, and it was used extensively in Vietnam.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Christopher Ammons was born in Norfolk, Virginia, on April 18, 1948. He enlisted in the Army on June 1, 1967, and served with the 1st Infantry Division and later with the 194th Military Police Company. Chris began his service as a replacement after the Tet Offensive and patrolled the Iron Triangle during his 1st tour. He briefly returned to the U.S. in 1968 and was stationed at the armory at Fort Bragg. He returned to Vietnam as an MP in 1969.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Christopher Ammons was born in Norfolk, Virginia, on April 18, 1948. He enlisted in the Army on June 1, 1967, and served with the 1st Infantry Division and later with the 194th Military Police Company. Chris began his service as a replacement after the Tet Offensive and patrolled the Iron Triangle during his 1st tour. He briefly returned to the US in 1968 and was stationed at the armory at Fort Bragg. He returned to Vietnam as an MP in 1969.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The UH-1 (or as it was originally designated the HU-1) "Huey" is one of the most recognizable and widely used helicopters in the world. During the Vietnam conflict, Hueys were used for many purposes including MedEvac, command and control, air assault, personnel and matriel transport, etc. It has several distinctive characteristics such as a rounded nose, a twin-bladed rotor, and the loud "whomp-whomp" sound the helicopter makes in flight. Approximately 7,000 UH-1 aircraft saw service in Vietnam.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lai Khe is a small settlement in Vietnam, to the northwest of Saigon (now Ho Chi Minh City). During the Vietnam War Lai Khe was a garrison town as the 5th Division of the Army of the Republic of Vietnam was based at Lai Khe. As a result Lai Khe and surrounding area attracted attention from the Vietnamese communist forces.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Propaganda

Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Military passes; Safe-conducts; Chieu Hoi Program; Counterinsurgency -- Vietnam; Political refugees -- Vietnam; Vietnam -- Politics and government -- 1945-1975; Propaganda; Leaflets dropped from aircraft; Intelligence service
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Chieu Hoi (Open Arms) program represents a 10-year psychological operation launched by the South Vietnamese government in April 1963 to encourage the "return" or "rally" of Viet-Cong, North Vietnamese Army soldiers, and Communist sympathizers. American involvement later came to dominate this pacification program. An estimated 160,000 defections occurred. The airdrop leaflet was the most commonly used item of inducement, but leaflets were also distributed by hand.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation:
Passport
Safe-conduct pass to honored by all Vietnamese government agencies and allied forces
By carrying this passport and
coordinating with the National
government you will:
Be kindly received
Have safety ensured
Be suitably treated
This Passport is valid with all military organizations of the Republic OF Vietnam and its allies (Translations provided by the Tennessee Foreign Language Institute)

Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Chieu Hoi Program; Counterinsurgency -- Vietnam; Political refugees -- Vietnam; Vietnam -- Politics and government -- 1945-1975; Propaganda; Leaflets dropped from aircraft; Intelligence service
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Chieu Hoi (Open Arms) program represents a 10-year psychological operation launched by the South Vietnamese government in April of 1963 to encourage the "return" or "rally" of Viet-Cong, North Vietnamese Army soldiers, and Communist sympathizers. American involvement later came to dominate this pacification program. An estimated 160,000 defections occurred. The airdrop leaflet was the most commonly used item of inducement, but leaflets were also distributed by hand.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Desire to go out. to present himself to hamlet or military post If you see any soldier who belongs to the Republic of Vietnam or Allied armed forces, you just need to raise your hands over your head and shout, Open arms! Designated Open Arms places will be established in provinces. Speakers from airplanes will inform you of where these places are located so that you can safely present yourselves there. If your Open arms surrender happens from one oclock in the morning, October 9, to midnight October 15, you will be eligible for a $2000 reward along with other benefits that are available to the returnees. You will be warmly welcomed and kindly treated. 246-131-68 (Translations provided by the Tennessee Foreign Language Institute)

Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Chieu Hoi Program; Counterinsurgency -- Vietnam; Political refugees -- Vietnam; Vietnam -- Politics and government -- 1945-1975; Propaganda; Leaflets dropped from aircraft; Intelligence service; Viet-Cong; Passes, Military
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Chieu Hoi (Open Arms) program represents a 10-year psychological operation launched by the South Vietnamese government in 1963 to encourage the "return" or "rally" of Viet-Cong, North Vietnamese Army soldiers, and Communist sympathizers. American involvement came to dominate this pacification program. The "SP" was an American code for "Special Project." The Viet-Cong exploited it, encouraging the idea that leaflets came from the people's government only. The code soon disappeared.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: (Translations provided by the Tennessee Foreign Language Institute)

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Chieu Hoi (Open Arms) program represents a 10-year psychological operation launched by the South Vietnamese government in April of 1963 to encourage the "return" or "rally" of Viet-Cong, North Vietnamese Army soldiers, and Communist sympathizers. American involvement later came to dominate this pacification program. Leaflets, loudspeakers, radio, film, newspapers, display items, rallies and performances, publications, and other media were all employed in the effort.

The armed forces of the Republic of Vietnam help people build a better life. (Translations provided by the Tennessee Foreign Language Institute)

Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Chieu Hoi Program; Counterinsurgency -- Vietnam; Political refugees -- Vietnam; Vietnam -- Politics and government -- 1945-1975; Propaganda; Leaflets dropped from aircraft; Intelligence service; Viet-Cong
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Chieu Hoi (Open Arms) program represents a 10-year psychological operation launched by the South Vietnamese government in April 1963. Defection was encouraged by using the five themes of Chieu Hoi: exploitation of ralliers, rally appeals, third party inducement, advertisement, and instructions on how to rally. Five billion leaflets were air-dropped over Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia in seven years.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation:

With the government of the Republic of Vietnam (Translations provided by the Tennessee Foreign Language Institute)

Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Chieu Hoi Program; Counterinsurgency -- Vietnam; Political refugees -- Vietnam; Vietnam -- Politics and government -- 1945-1975; Propaganda; Leaflets dropped from aircraft; Intelligence service; Viet-Cong
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Chieu Hoi (Open Arms) program represents a 10-year psychological operation launched by the South Vietnamese government in 1963 to encourage defection of Viet-Cong, North Vietnamese Army soldiers, and Communist sympathizers. Strategies included safe-conduct leaflets, rewards programs, returnees' testimonials, and a focus on being home for the Tet New Year. The enemy's weaknesses were gauged as fear, hardship, loss of faith in victory, concern for family, and disillusionment.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Are you suffering from starvation? To the cadres and soldiers belonging to the Front of the Liberation of South Vietnam and the North Vietnams armed forces! We know you are hiding in the deep forests, clinging to a hopeless ideology while you are facing starvation and an imminent death. Yoleaders at all levels have forsaken you. Your comrades have been killed. And you are alone. Why do you have to continue with this tragic and miserable life? Return to the National government! You will be warmly welcomed, kindly received, and have sufficient medical treatment. 6-163-6 (Translations provided by the Tennessee Foreign Language Institute)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chieu Hoi leaflet with weeping mother imagining son killed in fighting
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white two-sided propaganda leaflet conveys the anguish of a mother as she cries over the image she envisions of her son, killed in fighting. The leaflet number is on the front (SP.2141). The reverse contains a list of eleven advantages/rewards; received from the government by surrendering. Fifteen million copies of this leaflet were printed in December of 1967. Portions of the front image and theme would be incorporated into another leaflet that would feature a lengthy, sentimental poem.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mothers; Families; Dead persons; Dreaming

Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Chieu Hoi Program; Counterinsurgency -- Vietnam; Political refugees -- Vietnam; Vietnam -- Politics and government -- 1945-1975; Propaganda; Leaflets dropped from aircraft; Intelligence service
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Chieu Hoi (Open Arms) program represents a 10-year psychological operation launched by the South Vietnamese government in April 1963 to encourage the "return" or "rally" of Viet-Cong, North Vietnamese Army soldiers,; and Communist sympathizers. An estimated 160,000 defections occurred, but the program did not tend to sway hardcore Viet-Cong , North Vietnamese officers, or the more educated of enemy forces.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation:
I mourn for those who are dead and gone,
Your shattered family caused by those enslaved to Communism.
Your aged mother and tiny child: exhausted and bitter, but waiting still.
When will the day come, that day of togetherness? (Translations provided by the Tennessee Foreign Language Institute)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Handbook for U. S. forces in Vietnam
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Department of Defense pamphlet published for soldiers in combat in Vietnam. It provides text, illustrations, maps, and photographs. There are four chapters in the document, along with an appendix providing personal hygiene tips, a table, conversion and a road map of Vietnam. It contains military government document series codes at the top of the front cover.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Combat support; Tactics; Combat -- Handbooks, manuals, etc.; United States -- Armed Forces -- Handbooks, manuals, etc.; Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Guerrilla warfare -- Handbooks, manuals, etc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States. Dept. of Defense. Armed Forces Information and Education Division
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In an effort to provide increased effectiveness for U. S. armed forces in Vietnam, this handbook furnished information to soldiers about the Republic of Vietnam, the Viet-Cong, tactics and techniques, and combat support. This information was compiled from the experiences of those engaged in previous combat operations against the enemy.
